customData.content: 57-year-old man with stage III squamous cell lung cancer affecting the left mainstem bronchus, presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset of hemoptysis and severe respiratory distress. Patient had previously completed chemoradiation therapy. He reported a significant volume of continuous, bright red blood, exceeding 50 cc. He denied any prior history of hemoptysis, cough, fever, or chills.

HPI.summary: 57-year-old man with stage III squamous cell lung cancer affecting the left mainstem bronchus, presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset of hemoptysis and severe respiratory distress.

customData.content: Patient experiencing respiratory distress: Tachypnea (40 breaths per minute), sinus tachycardia at 144 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation as low as 79 % despite 100 % Fi02 via a non-rebreather mask. Physical examination revealed dried blood in the bilateral nares and oral cavity. Increased work of breathing, severe subcostal and intercostal retractions, and diminished breath sounds throughout both lung bases. Hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dl.

Normal platelet count and INR of 1. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed respiratory acidosis: pH 7.27, pCO2 54, pO2 94, bicarbonate 25. Patient was trialed on continuous positive pressure noninvasive ventilation but was unable to tolerate the mask due to anxiety. Coughed an additional 40-60 cc of bright red blood.

HPI.summary: Coughed an additional 40-60 cc of bright red blood.

customData.content: Patient intubated with a standard 8.0 endotracheal tube. Oxygen saturations improved to 97 % on 100 % FiO2, quickly decreased to 30 %. Frank blood visible from the endotracheal tube.

HPI.summary: Frank blood visible from the endotracheal tube.

customData.content: Emergent bronchoscopy revealed blood originating from the left lung. The posterior wall of the distal left mainstem bronchus was necrotic with evidence of a cavitary lesion in the superior segment of the left lower lobe extending into the lung parenchyma through which a large vessel could be seen.

procedures.name: Bronchoscopy
procedures.outcome: blood originating from the left lung

imaging.finding: posterior wall of the distal left mainstem bronchus was necrotic with evidence of a cavitary lesion in the superior segment of the left lower lobe extending into the lung parenchyma through which a large vessel could be seen.

customData.content: A 9-French endobronchial blocker was advanced into the proximal left mainstem bronchus under direct visualization.

Hemoglobin levels nadired at 7.4 g/dl. Bronchoscopic image of cavitary lesion in left lower lobe superior segment showed visible pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm. CT chest angiogram with IV contrast showed contrast enhancing pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm within cavitary lesion. Segmental left lower lobe pseudoaneurysm without extravasation.

imaging.finding: cavitary lesion with visible pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
contrast enhancing pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm within cavitary lesion
imaging.impression: Segmental left lower lobe pseudoaneurysm without extravasation

customData.content: Patient underwent left main pulmonary artery angiography with interventional radiology demonstrating a segmental left lower lobe pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm without extravasation. A 5-French catheter was used to select the contributing inferior and posterior pulmonary artery branches, at which point a high flow microcatheter was advanced and the segmental branch from which the pseudoaneurysm arose was embolized using platinum coils. A persistent communication to the pseudoaneurysm was seen and a mesh plug was deployed to embolize the remaining proximal branch. Repeat arteriography demonstrated no further filling of the pseudoaneurysm and preservation of the nearby segmental artery.

procedures.name: Embolization
procedures.location: segmental branch from which the pseudoaneurysm arose

imaging.finding: segmental left lower lobe pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm without extravasation
imaging.impression: segmental left lower lobe pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm without extravasation

customData.content: One month after discharge, the patient suffered a cardiac arrest in the setting of recurrent massive hemoptysis and died after a brief hospitalization.

data.content: Progression of hemoptysis and respiratory distress leading to hypoxia and abnormal vital signs.
Respiratory distress worsened, leading to respiratory acidosis despite non-invasive ventilation attempt. Continued hemoptysis.
Worsening respiratory status necessitating intubation, followed by desaturation and frank blood in the endotracheal tube.
Bronchoscopy performed to investigate hemoptysis, revealing a necrotic lesion and a visible large vessel in the left lower lobe.
Endobronchial blocker placed to control bleeding from the left lung.
Hemoglobin levels decreased. Imaging revealed a pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm within the cavitary lesion.
Pulmonary artery angiography and embolization performed to treat the pseudoaneurysm.
Recurrent massive hemoptysis leading to cardiac arrest and death one month post-discharge.
